Overview

The Robix Usbor Software is written entirely in Java (except for some JNI code which is needed to access hardware). We like Java for its portability, ease-of-use, and multi-threaded architecture. If you have a choice of programming languages, we recommend writing your Usbor application in Java and using our Java Nexway API. Since Java is our language-of-choice, our Java API is likely to be more extensive, better documented, and more rigorously tested.

We realize that Java is not for everyone, which is why we provide the Nexway Library (sometimes referred to in this document simply as NexwayLib). The Nexway library is a simple C-style library shell around our Java classes. You'll still need Java installed on your system, but you can write your Usbor applications in C, C++, or Visual Basic.

The NexwayLib API provides basic C functions that mirror those provided by our Java API. If you look at both API's, you'll notice that the NexwayLib API is actually a subset of the functionality provided by our Java API. We've tried to provide enough features to satisfy the needs of our users, but the NexwayLib API is not intended to be used as the basis for large, graphical application. New features may be added if the need becomes evident and time allows.


Java Requirements

A Java(tm) Virtual Machine (JVM) is required by the Nexway library. Our Java classes, and hence the Nexway library, require Java version 1.4 or greater. See the Readme.txt file included with this software package for a guide to installing Java on your computer.


Locating the Java VM

By default, the Nexway library will try to automatically find a suitable JVM on your system. If you have performed a typical Java installation, the automatic JVM search should be successful. If you encounter problems during JVM initialization, or if you have special needs, you may specify a JVM as described below.

Windows users:
The Nexway Library searches the Windows registry for information about the current installed JVM. As of this writing, only JVM's from Sun are supported.
Mac OSX users:
The Nexway Library searches for a JVM in the following order:
  1. The directory specified by the JAVA_HOME environment variable (if present).
  2. The directory: $HOME/Library/Frameworks/JavaVM.framework, where $HOME is the current user's home directory.
  3. The directory: /System/Library/Frameworks/JavaVM.framework
The search stops as soon as a suitable JVM is found.
Linux users:
The Nexway Library searches for a JVM in the following order:
  1. The directory specified by the JAVA_HOME environment variable (if present).
  2. Sub-directories of: $HOME/java, where $HOME is the current user's home directory.
  3. Sub-directories of: /usr/java.
The search stops as soon as a suitable JVM is found.

Including the Nexway Library in a Project

Applications which need to call functions in the Nexway library should #include "rbxNexwayLib.h", which is located in the 'include' directory of this software package. Usually, you'll want to specify the Robix include directory in your project's "Additional Include Directories".
For default installations: 
   (Windows) C:\Program Files\Robix\Usbor\include
   (Mac OSX) /Applications/Robix/Usbor/include
   (Linux)   /opt/Robix/Usbor/include

The NexwayLib header file contains an inline function which dynamically loads the Nexway library and assigns function pointers at runtime. Therefore, it is not necessary to change any of your project's linker settings.

Important: #define RBX_MAIN needed once

Your application may contain many source code files, and you may need to #include "rbxNexwayLib.h" in more than one of your source code files. Regardless of the number of files which include the NexwayLib header file, one and only one source code file must #define RBX_MAIN before including rbxNexwayLib.h--preferably the main source code file. This is necessary to prevent redeclaration of function pointers.

Example: multiple source files
Consider an application that contains three source files: MainForm.cpp, SubForm.cpp, and DialogForm.cpp.
rbxNexwayLib.h can be included as follows:
  In MainForm.cpp: 
    #define RBX_MAIN
    #include "rbxNexwayLib.h"
  In SubForm.cpp and DialogForm.cpp: 
    #include "rbxNexwayLib.h"
Example: single source file
Consider an application that contains only one source file.
rbxNexwayLib.h should be included as follows:
    #define RBX_MAIN
    #include "rbxNexwayLib.h"
If you forget to #define RBX_MAIN, you might receive an error like this:
    Error: Unresolved signal: [library function name]

If you #define RBX_MAIN more than once, you might receive an error like this:
    Error: Multiple declaration of: [library function name]

Important: rbxInitNexwayLib() must be called first

Applications must call rbxInitNexwayLib() before calling any other functions in the Nexway library. This function dynamically loads the library, sets up function pointers, and invokes the JVM.


Locating the Nexway Library and Usbor JAR

By default, the inline function rbxInitNexwayLib() will try to automatically find the Nexway library and the Usbor JAR on your system. If you installed the Usbor Software to the default location, the automatic search should be successful. If you encounter problems during NexwayLib initialization, or if you have special needs, review the search algorithm described below.

Most users will usually call the simplified rbxInitNexwayLib() function (which in turn calls rbxInitNexwayLibEx(), specifying NULL for the libPath and jarPath parameters). The inline function rbxInitNexwayLibEx() tries to load the Nexway library and the Usbor JAR according to the following rules:

  • If parameter libPath is not NULL, the specified path is tried. If an error occurs, the function immediately returns an error code.
  • If parameter libPath is NULL, the the following directories are searched for the library (in the order shown here):
    1. The current working directory. (This can be helpful when deploying your Usbor application.)
    2. $USBOR_HOME/lib where $USBOR_HOME is the value of the environment variable USBOR_HOME (if present).
    3. RBX_USBOR_INSTALL_DIR/lib where RBX_USBOR_INSTALL_DIR is a hard-coded string defined in rbxNexwayLib.h (and rbxNexwayLib.bas for VB). Note that RBX_USBOR_INSTALL_DIR is not automatically set by the installer program, so you may need to edit rbxNexwayLib.h and/or rbxNexwayLib.bas if you did not install the Usbor Software to the default location.
  • If parameter jarPath is not NULL, the specified path is tried. If an error occurs, the function immediately returns an error code.
  • If parameter jarPath is NULL, the directories listed above are searched for the JAR file.


Nexway-Nexus Relationship

Controlling Usbor Pods (aka Robots, Organs, ...) requires two major components, a Nexus and a Nexway.

The Nexus is a stand-alone application which communicates directly with Usbor devices through USB. The Nexus then provides access to the Usbors via TCP/IP connections.

A Nexway is, as the name implies, a "gateway to the Nexus". A Nexway establishes a TCP/IP connection to the Nexus in order to control Pods.

In many respects, a Nexway-Nexus connection can be viewed as a client-server relationship. A single Nexus (server) can accept connections from many Nexways (clients). A single Nexway may connect to several Nexi (plural of Nexus) simultaneously. A single computer can host only one Nexus but many Nexways.


Object Hierarchy

The Nexway is the entry point to this API and the root of an object hierarchy as shown below.

  Nexway
  |
  '---NexusConnection*
      |
      '---Usbor*
          |
          '---Pod*
              |
              '---Servo*
              '---Digout*
              '---Sensor*
  * zero or more


Controlling Pods (aka Robots, Organs, ...)

General steps necessary to control pods:

  • Make sure the Nexus application is running on local (or remote) computer.
  • Load and initialize the Nexway Library by calling rbxInitNexwayLib() (which creates an implied Nexway object).
  • Create a NexusConnection object.
  • Connect to the local (or remote) Nexus application.
  • "Discover" Usbors that are provided by the Nexus.
  • "Discover" Pods that are provided by the Usbor.
  • Once you have a handle to a Pod, you can run scripts, read sensors, monitor servo positions, etc.

These steps are illustrated in the example programs which accompany the Usbor software.

It is important to understand that Pod commands (rbxPod_assignMainScript(), rbxPod_runMainMacro(), #rbsPod_stopScript(), etc.) are executed asynchronously and may even be queued if the Pod is busy.

For example, when you call rbxPod_runQuickScript(), the method does not wait for the script to execute--the method returns immediately, and the script will run "later". When is "later"? It depends. If you are connected to a Nexus on your local computer, a message may travel so quickly that it appears instantaneous. On the other hand, if you are connected to a Nexus that is on the other side of the globe, it may be some time before your script reaches its destination. It is not the intent of this API (nor the Usbor software system) to provide time-critical Pod control. Rather, we provide a more "relaxed" approach to control and sensory observation.


Handles

As mentioned above, the Nexway library is simply a C-style wrapper for our Java classes. In our Java API, objects and methods are accessed through object references (much like pointers in C/C++). The Nexway library API, however, does not provide direct pointers to objects. Instead, we refer to an object by the object's handle. For ease-of-use, a handle is simply an int, and should be treated as opaque, i.e. the int value has no special meaning except as a look-up value used by the Nexway library.

You can see how object referencing differs between our Java API and our NexwayLib API in the following snippits of code. Both examples perform exactly the same operation. (Error-checking has been omitted for simplicity.)

Java API
    NexusConnection newNexus;
    newNexus = Nexway.createNexusConnection( "localhost" );
    newNexus.connect();
C-style NexwayLib API
    int newNexusHandle;
    rbxNexway_createNexusConnection( "localhost", &newNexusHandle );
    rbxNexus_connect( newNexusHandle );
Note that throughout the NexwayLib API, valid handles are always non-zero. This allows us to return a handle value of zero when we want to indicate "no object found", instead of returning an error code. For an example of this technique, see rbxNexusConnection_getUsborByName().


Robix Error Codes

Another difference betwen our Java API and our NexwayLib API is how errors are reported to the application. In Java, exceptions are thrown and can be caught. In the Nexway library, Robix Error Codes are returned from all functions to indicate success or failure. Programmers should always check return codes after calling NexwayLib functions.

Certain error codes are generic and may be returned by any NexwayLib function (even if the doc does not explictly say so).

Generic error codes include:

  • RBX_E_SUCCESS
  • RBX_E_GENERAL_EXCEPTION
  • RBX_E_MEMORY_ALLOCATION
  • RBX_E_JVM_NOT_INITIALIZED
  • RBX_E_NULL_POINTER
  • RBX_E_ILLEGAL_ARGUMENT
  • RBX_E_BUFFER_TOO_SMALL

Other error codes are more specific to certain functions. The docs for individual functions describe when/if they return any specialized error codes. For an example, see #rbxNexus_connect().

Note:
When diplaying Robix error codes, always prefix them with "RBX_" to prevent confusion with system error codes. For example, 
 "Error connecting to Nexus. Error Code: RBX_2003"
See also:
rbxLib_getErrMsg()

Fetching Strings

Some functions in the Nexway library are used to fetch a string, such as rbxNexway_getName(). Such functions copy the requested string into a user-allocated buffer. User code must also provide the size of the buffer to prevent buffer overruns.

Fetching a string typically requires the following steps:

  1. Get the length of the string to be fetched.
  2. Allocate a buffer to receive the string.
  3. Fetch the string.

To get the length of a string, call the string-fetching function with NULL as the buffer parameter and 0 (zero) as the buffer size. The function will return RBX_E_BUFFER_TOO_SMALL and the retLen parameter will contain the required buffer size (including the null-terminator).

Note:
All strings returned by the Nexway library are null-terminated.
Example:
    int siz;

    // get size of Nexway name
    if ( rbxNexway_getName( NULL, 0, &siz )
            == RBX_E_BUFFER_TOO_SMALL )
    {
       // allocate space for Nexway name
       char* nexwayName = (char*)malloc( siz );
       if ( nexwayName )
       {
          // fetch Nexway name
          if ( rbxNexway_getName( nexwayName, siz, NULL )
                  == RBX_E_SUCCESS )
          {
             printf( "Got Nexway name: %s", nexwayName );
          }
          free( nexwayName );
       }
    }
There is one more detail about fetching strings. If you specify a buffer size, maxLen, which is less than the required buffer size, your buffer will receive maxLen characters (including a null-terminator), and the function will return RBX_E_BUFFER_TOO_SMALL. This behavior allows you to detect when your buffer is too small, and it also allows you to gracefully fetch a truncated string if you desire.

Troubleshooting

If you encounter problems using the Nexway Library:
  • Visit our forums www.robix.com.
  • Send bug reports to bugs@robix.com


History

1.0.0 -- 2005-02-28
  • added new functions:
    • rbxNexway_getNexusConnectionCount()
    • rbxNexway_getNexusConnection()
    • rbxNexway_getNexusConnectionListMod()
  • renamed rbxNexus_Xxx functions to rbxNexusConnection_Xxx
  • renamed functions:
    • rbxNexus_getConnectionLocation() -> rbxNexusConnection_getRepLocation()
    • rbxNexus_getAvgResponseTimeMs() -> rbxNexusConnection_getRepResponseTimeMs()
    • rbxUsbor_getNexus() -> rbxUsbor_getNexusConnection()
    • rbxUsbor_getConnectionLocation() -> rbxUsbor_getRepLocation()
    • rbxUsbor_getAvgResponseTimeMs() -> rbxUsbor_getRepResponseTimeMs()
  • removed functions:
    • rbxFreeNexwayLib()
    • rbxNexus_getConnectionType()
    • rbxUsbor_getConnectionType()

0.0.12.1 -- 2005-02-05

  • #define MAIN changed to #define RBX_MAIN
  • removed #undef MAIN from example text
  • define RBX_USBOR_ROOT changed to RBX_USBOR_INSTALL_DIR
  • removed defines RBX_NEXWAYLIB_PATH and RBX_USBORJAR_PATH

0.0.12 -- 2005-02-03

  • created documentation

0.0.9 -- 2004-09-25

  • initial library release
  • undocumented
